bioghist.p: Joseph George Rosengarten was born in 1835. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1852. In 1856 he was admitted to the bar, and in 1857 traveled to Heidelberg to study Roman law. During the Civil War Rosengarten served on the staff of General John F. Reynolds. He was the author of The German Soldier in the Wars of the United States and The Sources of German-American History. Rosengarten was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of Pennsylvania and a chairman of the Trustee's Library Committee.

scopecontent.p: The collection consists of manuscripts and correspondence by or collected by Rosengarten. Extra-illustrated bound works by Rosengarten include an interleaved copy of The German Soldier in the Wars of the United States, with documents and letters mounted, German Allied Troops in the War of Independence, General Count de Rochambeau and The Chateau de Rochambeau. Correspondence includes letters to Rosengarten, some related to manuscripts or letters sent to him (many are notes of thanks for copies of his book French Colonists and Exiles in the United States), and letters collected by Rosengarten -- most from the Revolutionary War period, in French, German, and English. Corespondents include: Madame de Stael, Tallyrand, Francois Chateaubriand, Frederick II of Prussia, James Hamilton, Francis Hopkinson, John Jay, and George Clinton. There is a bound manuscript copy of Poppâ€™s Journal, 1777-1783 by Joseph G. Rosengarten and a bound collection of German manuscripts dealing with the Revolutionary War in the U.S. [1776-1782], including diaries of Caspar Recknagel, Andreas Wiederhold and reports on the Battle of Trenton, which include maps, illustrations, and charts (some of the maps have been removed and unfolded). The collection also includes a 1992 translation of The Diary of Caspar Recknagel (translation by Bruce E. Burgoyne) and negatives and photographs of manuscript pages, maps, and engravings.
